Option (2) is likely better, as the user does not have to select a type in (1). 
I.e. they may just type in a qualified name.
oops - source lookup requires a stack frame, not a type name. Hmmm.

I thought that a project was always associated to a java launch config.

I think (2) should work, as we can get a stack frame from a view (launch view
may be).

I'm going to check how we get the stack frame for the display view and the
detail pane.

Yes, source lookup should work... get the stack frame, then get the source 
element (CU or Classfile) for the stack frame, and get the Java project from 
that frame. That should be sufficient for a compilation context.
If  you cannot get a project context, you can just do the standard 'toString()'.

I implemented that. There is just one 'problem', I have to put the code which
determine the current project in JDIModelePresentation. Two reasons for that :
- I have to use the method DebugUITools.getDebugContext(), which return the
context only if it is call in the UI thread.
- As the requests for detail of values are put in the queue, the context may be
different between when the request is done and when the detail is evaluated.

btw, I haven't seen anything which remove a request from the queue if it is no
longer valid. Is it normal ?

Fixed.

Changes in JDIModelPresentation and JavaDetailFormattersManager
